title: Grid vs Flexbox Quiz
description: Test your understanding of CSS Grid and Flexbox layout systems.

questions.question: Which layout system is best for two-dimensional layouts (rows AND columns)?
questions.explanation: CSS Grid is designed for two-dimensional layouts, controlling both rows and columns simultaneously. Flexbox works along a single axis.

questions.question: What does the 'fr' unit represent in CSS Grid?

options.text: A fixed ratio of the viewport
A fractional unit of available space

questions.explanation: The 'fr' unit distributes remaining available space in the grid container proportionally after fixed-size tracks are accounted for.

questions.question: The 'gap' property works only in CSS Grid, not in Flexbox.
questions.explanation: The 'gap' property works in both CSS Grid and Flexbox in all modern browsers. It provides consistent spacing between items.

questions.question: Which property controls the main axis direction in Flexbox?
questions.explanation: flex-direction controls the main axis: row (default), row-reverse, column, or column-reverse.

questions.question: What does repeat(auto-fit, minmax(200px, 1fr)) create?

options.text: A responsive grid where columns are at least 200px wide
A grid with 200px gaps between items

questions.explanation: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(200px, 1fr)) creates a responsive grid where columns are minimum 200px wide and expand evenly to fill available space. No media queries needed.

questions.question: What is the shortest way to center an item both horizontally and vertically with Grid?
questions.explanation: place-items: center is a shorthand that sets both align-items and justify-items to center, achieving perfect centering with a single property.

questions.question: When flex items wrap to multiple lines, each line is laid out independently.
questions.explanation: Flexbox is fundamentally one-dimensional. When items wrap, each line distributes space independently. For true grid alignment across rows, use CSS Grid instead.
